column2: Let the future and the furthest be the motive of thy to-day; in thy friend shalt thou love the Superman as thy motive.
column3: Let the future and the furthest be the motive of thy to day; in thy friend shalt thou love the Superman as thy motive.

column2: My brethren, I advise you not to neighbour-love--I advise you to furthest love!--
column3: My brethren, I advise you not to neighbour love-I advise you to furthest love!--

column2: Thus spake Zarathustra.
column3: Thus spake Zarathustra.

column2: XVII.
column3: seventeen.

column2: THE WAY OF THE CREATING ONE.
column3: THE WAY OF THE CREATING ONE.

column2: Wouldst thou go into isolation, my brother?
column3: Wouldst thou go into isolation, my brother?

column2: Wouldst thou seek the way unto thyself?
column3: Wouldst thou seek the way unto thyself?

column2: Tarry yet a little and hearken unto me.
column3: Tarry yet a little and hearken unto me.

column2: He who seeketh may easily get lost himself.	He who seeketh may easily get lost himself.
column3: true

column2: All isolation is wrong": so say the herd.
column3: All isolation is wrong": so say the herd.

column2: And long didst thou belong to the herd.
column3: And long didst thou belong to the herd.

column2: The voice of the herd will still echo in thee.
column3: The voice of the herd will still echo in thee.

column2: And when thou sayest, "I have no longer a conscience in common with you," then will it be a plaint and a pain.
column3: And when thou sayest, "I have no longer a conscience in common with you," then will it be a plaint and a pain.

column2: Lo, that pain itself did the same conscience produce; and the last gleam of that conscience still gloweth on thine affliction.
column3: Lo, that pain itself did the same conscience produce; and the last gleam of that conscience still gloweth on thine affliction.

column2: But thou wouldst go the way of thine affliction, which is the way unto thyself?
column3: But thou wouldst go the way of thine affliction, which is the way unto thyself?

column2: Then show me thine authority and thy strength to do so!
column3: Then show me thine authority and thy strength to do so!

column2: Art thou a new strength and a new authority?
column3: Art thou a new strength and a new authority?

column2: A first motion?
column3: A first motion?

column2: A self-rolling wheel?
column3: A self rolling wheel?

column2: Canst thou also compel stars to revolve around thee?
column3: Canst thou also compel stars to revolve around thee?

column2: Alas! there is so much lusting for loftiness!
column3: Alas! there is so much lusting for loftiness!

column2: There are so many convulsions of the ambitions!
column3: There are so many convulsions of the ambitions!

column2: Show me that thou art not a lusting and ambitious one!
column3: Show me that thou art not a lusting and ambitious one!

column2: Alas! there are so many great thoughts that do nothing more than the bellows: they inflate, and make emptier than ever.
column3: Alas! there are so many great thoughts that do nothing more than the bellows: they inflate, and make emptier than ever.

column2: Free, dost thou call thyself?
column3: Free, dost thou call thyself?

column2: Thy ruling thought would I hear of, and not that thou hast escaped from a yoke.
column3: Thy ruling thought would I hear of, and not that thou hast escaped from a yoke.

column2: Art thou one ENTITLED to escape from a yoke?
column3: Art thou one ENTITLED to escape from a yoke?

column2: Many a one hath cast away his final worth when he hath cast away his servitude.
column3: Many a one hath cast away his final worth when he hath cast away his servitude.

column2: Free from what?
column3: Free from what?

column2: What doth that matter to Zarathustra!
column3: What doth that matter to Zarathustra!

column2: Clearly, however, shall thine eye show unto me: free FOR WHAT?
column3: Clearly, however, shall thine eye show unto me: free FOR WHAT?

column2: Canst thou give unto thyself thy bad and thy good, and set up thy will as a law over thee?
column3: Canst thou give unto thyself thy bad and thy good, and set up thy will as a law over thee?

column2: Canst thou be judge for thyself, and avenger of thy law?
column3: Canst thou be judge for thyself, and avenger of thy law?

column2: Terrible is aloneness with the judge and avenger of one's own law. Thus is a star projected into desert space, and into the icy breath of aloneness.
column3: Terrible is aloneness with the judge and avenger of one's own law. Thus is a star projected into desert space, and into the icy breath of aloneness.

column2: To-day sufferest thou still from the multitude, thou individual; to-day hast thou still thy courage unabated, and thy hopes.
column3: To day sufferest thou still from the multitude, thou individual; to day hast thou still thy courage unabated, and thy hopes.

column2: But one day will the solitude weary thee; one day will thy pride yield, and thy courage quail.
column3: But one day will the solitude weary thee; one day will thy pride yield, and thy courage quail.

column2: Thou wilt one day cry: "I am alone!"
column3: Thou wilt one day cry: "I am alone!"

column2: One day wilt thou see no longer thy loftiness, and see too closely thy lowliness; thy sublimity itself will frighten thee as a phantom.
column3: One day wilt thou see no longer thy loftiness, and see too closely thy lowliness; thy sublimity itself will frighten thee as a phantom.

column2: Thou wilt one day cry: "All is false!"
column3: Thou wilt one day cry: "All is false!"

column2: There are feelings which seek to slay the lonesome one; if they do not succeed, then must they themselves die!
column3: There are feelings which seek to slay the lonesome one; if they do not succeed, then must they themselves die!

column2: But art thou capable of it--to be a murderer?
column3: But art thou capable of it-to be a murderer?

column2: Hast thou ever known, my brother, the word "disdain"?
column3: Hast thou ever known, my brother, the word "disdain"?

column2: And the anguish of thy justice in being just to those that disdain thee?
column3: And the anguish of thy justice in being just to those that disdain thee?

column2: Thou forcest many to think differently about thee; that, charge they heavily to thine account.
column3: Thou forcest many to think differently about thee; that, charge they heavily to thine account.

column2: Thou camest nigh unto them, and yet wentest past: for that they never forgive thee.
column3: Thou camest nigh unto them, and yet wentest past: for that they never forgive thee.

column2: Thou goest beyond them: but the higher thou risest, the smaller doth the eye of envy see thee.
column3: Thou goest beyond them: but the higher thou risest, the smaller doth the eye of envy see thee.

column2: Most of all, however, is the flying one hated.
column3: Most of all, however, is the flying one hated.

column2: How could ye be just unto me!--must thou say--"I choose your injustice as my allotted portion."
column3: How could ye be just unto me!--must thou say-"I choose your injustice as my allotted portion."

column2: Injustice and filth cast they at the lonesome one: but, my brother, if thou wouldst be a star, thou must shine for them none the less on that account!
column3: Injustice and filth cast they at the lonesome one: but, my brother, if thou wouldst be a star, thou must shine for them none the less on that account!

column2: And be on thy guard against the good and just!
column3: And be on thy guard against the good and just!

column2: They would fain crucify those who devise their own virtue--they hate the lonesome ones.
column3: They would fain crucify those who devise their own virtue-they hate the lonesome ones.

column2: Be on thy guard, also, against holy simplicity!
column3: Be on thy guard, also, against holy simplicity!

column2: All is unholy to it that is not simple; fain, likewise, would it play with the fire--of the fagot and stake.
column3: All is unholy to it that is not simple; fain, likewise, would it play with the fire-of the fagot and stake.

column2: And be on thy guard, also, against the assaults of thy love!
column3: And be on thy guard, also, against the assaults of thy love!

column2: Too readily doth the recluse reach his hand to any one who meeteth him.
column3: Too readily doth the recluse reach his hand to any one who meeteth him.

column2: To many a one mayest thou not give thy hand, but only thy paw; and I wish thy paw also to have claws.
column3: To many a one mayest thou not give thy hand, but only thy paw; and I wish thy paw also to have claws.

column2: But the worst enemy thou canst meet, wilt thou thyself always be; thou waylayest thyself in caverns and forests.
column3: But the worst enemy thou canst meet, wilt thou thyself always be; thou waylayest thyself in caverns and forests.

column2: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way to thyself!
column3: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way to thyself!

column2: And past thyself and thy seven devils leadeth thy way!
column3: And past thyself and thy seven devils leadeth thy way!

column2: A heretic wilt thou be to thyself, and a wizard and a sooth-sayer, and a fool, and a doubter, and a reprobate, and a villain.
column3: A heretic wilt thou be to thyself, and a wizard and a sooth sayer, and a fool, and a doubter, and a reprobate, and a villain.

column2: Ready must thou be to burn thyself in thine own flame; how couldst thou become new if thou have not first become ashes!
column3: Ready must thou be to burn thyself in thine own flame; how couldst thou become new if thou have not first become ashes!

column2: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way of the creating one: a God wilt thou create for thyself out of thy seven devils!
column3: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way of the creating one: a God wilt thou create for thyself out of thy seven devils!

column2: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way of the loving one: thou lovest thyself, and on that account despisest thou thyself, as only the loving ones despise.
column3: Thou lonesome one, thou goest the way of the loving one: thou lovest thyself, and on that account despisest thou thyself, as only the loving ones despise.

column2: To create, desireth the loving one, because he despiseth!
column3: To create, desireth the loving one, because he despiseth!

column2: What knoweth he of love who hath not been obliged to despise just what he loved!
column3: What knoweth he of love who hath not been obliged to despise just what he loved!

column2: With thy love, go into thine isolation, my brother, and with thy creating; and late only will justice limp after thee.
column3: With thy love, go into thine isolation, my brother, and with thy creating; and late only will justice limp after thee.

column2: With my tears, go into thine isolation, my brother.
column3: With my tears, go into thine isolation, my brother.

column2: I love him who seeketh to create beyond himself, and thus succumbeth.--
column3: I love him who seeketh to create beyond himself, and thus succumbeth.--

column2: Thus spake Zarathustra.
column3: Thus spake Zarathustra.

column2: XVIII.
column3: eighteen.

column2: OLD AND YOUNG WOMEN.
column3: OLD AND YOUNG WOMEN.

column2: Why stealest thou along so furtively in the twilight, Zarathustra?	Why stealest thou along so furtively in the twilight, Zarathustra?
column3: false

column2: And what hidest thou so carefully under thy mantle?
column3: And what hidest thou so carefully under thy mantle?
